data.message: Yes - I thought it was a good idea to start with the basics and then working up to the advanced stuff. Is there something special you would like to read about?
I'm looking into integrating react with an express app. I'm currently reviewing express tutorials and documentation to get me going. The MERN framework

In terms of Server Side Rendering? That's a bit difficoult. 

But if you mean you have an express backend (REST API) you would fetch the data from there - this is part of my next article in the series :) Or did I misunderstand something?

If you want to create a Express Backend AND a React App that gets the data from it, I would suggest you have a look at how to create an Express REST API first. 
Then learn how to fetch data from a backend (fetch, axios, superagent, etc) 

I think that's the best way to go there.
Thank you
Aaron James you're welcome! I'm always happy to help :)
are you going to tackle advanced react topics in the future?
Thank you! I started with the basic topics and work my way up yo the advanced stuff :) besides, I'm writing React for Noobs - an eBook that leads through all of this
Do u also make video tutorials?

Chandra Kishore Bakshi I think about doing video tutorials after the book is finished - if people like it, I'm going further in that direction. Video tutorials would be nice - I think it would even fit better to what I do because I can explain things better when you can point to certain areas in the source code. 

So if I got the time after the book is finished, I'm going to try one video to see how people like it and get feedback, and the next stop is a full course :)
Andreas Reiterer When is your book going to finish?

As I hit the goal of subscribers that I set myself, I started my research and plan to publish the first chapter by the end of the year. As the research and the start is most of the work, I think the whole book will be out somewhere in March/April. 
But I plan to add a preorder option so people can get the chapters as they are ready, so they don't have to wait until the whole book is finished.

I see many people talking about Vue and how they prefer it over React.  The common argument is simplicity and performance.  Simplicity is nice, but I don't see how it scales well - observables can be a mess and can create performance issues when scaling.  For those that understand what "immutability helpers" are and understand how they increase performance at scale for React (no, they are not common utility functions), can you explain how Vue might scale?

I want to understand Vue better, I feel like maybe I'm missing something.
Vue has also single file component which is easily scalable. Tons of pugins and the community is great.
Having to work with vue for a year now, definitely not a jquery-esque tho. It has also its lifecycles like react does. I think its more of a combination of react and angular.

Does it have any mechanism that handles fast rendering from small mutations within large data sets?

For example, I can use ImmutableJS in React and it will generate mutation data for React to consume.

Or is this addressed differently in the architecture?
Shawn Khameneh after a quick search for ImmutableJS. there is actually built in Vue.set and Vue.delete. https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#Vue-set.
Interesting, nested observables?
Oh, that's single dimension.  ImmutableJS will do multidimensional IIRC.
i havent tested it but i think it can handle multidimensional. sample: Vue.set(this.array['foo'], key, value).
Does the data mutation get signaled to the parent container?
im not sure but when using Vue.set and Vue.delete, updated() would trigger. thats what im always using.
https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#updated
Is Vue just the jQuery-esque these days?  Or does it actually scale like React?

I personally find React code much cleaner, although VUE is definitely easier to setup since you don't even need a builder (it's more like angularJS).

I'm not a fan of the html & js files having used angular for 3 years, and really like the JSX approach. At the end of the day, all of these frameworks are so fast that you don't really see a difference anymore.
Doesn’t matter. You learn react to be able to use react native. Which is the hotter technology. And btw you are asking this question in the wrong channel.
React is a framework ? Great you have some extra knowledge. Thanks for sharing.
Comparing a library with a framework. Wrong question,yeah wrong channel too...

Vue is easier to learn for beginners. It is also easier to integrate with php if you use symfony or laravel as your main framework. React is definitely a way to go for javascript only production projects.

I have a repo with redux-form CRUD. But there is also a recompose and graphql so it might be a little bit harder to understand. However redux-form itself is really simple.

1) You have to create form:
https://github.com/developer239/ReactReduxApolloGraphQLHotBoilerplate/blob/master/src/modules/blog/forms/Post/index.js

You can change component={TitleInput} to component="input"
You can change component={TextTextArea} to component="textarea"

I am using react bootstrap. Also I will refactor those custom components in the future. I took them from my old project and they are a mess.

2) Using form is easy. You just have to import it and use it in render method of your page component.
https://github.com/developer239/ReactReduxApolloGraphQLHotBoilerplate/blob/master/src/pages/Blog/PostCreate/index.js#L13

3) You have to define onSubmit={handleOnSubmit} handler. That function will get form data as a first parameter.

https://github.com/developer239/ReactReduxApolloGraphQLHotBoilerplate/blob/master/src/pages/Blog/PostCreate/index.js#L29

Notice that onSubmit and handleSubmit is NOT the same thing.

That is it. If you want to edit existing data simply pass the data as initialValues prop. :)

https://github.com/developer239/ReactReduxApolloGraphQLHotBoilerplate/blob/master/src/pages/Blog/PostEdit/index.js#L14

There is also really good example in their official documentation:  https://redux-form.com/7.0.4/examples/simple/

thank you I will look in to this :) yes, seems redux-from quit complicated, but I needed  long form with added field arrays, seemed clear example they have and I am just new to react and software development at all :)

I have a project of react native. I am using redux saga for handling side effects.
Currently, I am able to get data from API in my saga and then I save data to store.
.
.
Is there a way to directly return that data from saga to the react native component ?

Just curiosity.
So that I can use data directly in my component without altering the store.
If the effect is local to your component then can't you just do the fetch in a lifecycle method and set state?

Yeah I know that solution. But I just want to know whether there is something like that in redux saga or not because most of the api related work I am doing in redux saga so I thought that could be managed over there as well.
Why do you want to do that

Yeah I know that. 
Thanks for your time. 😊
No because redux is designed to pass data one way only. Returning data directly to component would be anti-pattern.
It can be, but you have to use redux to get data from saga

Hi guys.

I need suggestion for best practice regarding role system between API and React. 

I want to achieve is show navigation menu based on admin Role (Marketing, Cashier, etc). Any good example?

Right now I'm thinking about retrieve navigation menus from API (but idk is it a good practice or not because it going to add additional query)
sounds great idea!. Is it safe to expose the navigation menu within API response?

I think so, if your server actually checks (1) that the session is alive and (2) that the user is allowed to access the API according to his role.

If you are using HTTPS (which you probably should do for any request with username/password) then nobody can pick the response observing the traffic. If you are using HTTPS for everything, I don’t think you should worry at all.
thanks Vlad Balin!. Really helpful. been wondering for 2 days for best practice.

Yes. You’re generating them from the menu object.
Vlad Balin on the fly?
In exactly the same way you usually do in SPA. You just delay its initialization up to the moment when you have menu object.

You can receive menu structure as a part of the authorization request response.

Like this: POST /api { login, password } => { roles, menu, ...others }

When you app loads, you could check if you still have alive session with GET /api, which would either return you the same object as above or “Not authorized” HTTP error. In the last case you redirect to the login page.

This “session” object is also the good place to transmit all the global data your app will need.

A bit tricky on reactJS. I created custom react-router to handle auth & authorization. You need pass session to react component. I suggest implement JWT.

First, you need login page and save JWT on localStorage
Second, You need pass session to every page.
Third, You need pass JTW token when call to server

Then from session information, you can decide to block whole page or just some part.

To block whole page, you need create "Parent" component where you put authorization logic.

There are multiple issues here:

1) In JavaScript, you can't put multiple statements after 'return'. The return statement is always the last thing in a function body.
2) With React, you should not be interacting with `window` or `document` inside a component's render method. You should use life-cycle methods inside the component (like `componentDidMount`, etc.).

I suggest you spend some time going back over basic JS syntax, and then read the React docs before tackling more complex topics, such as canvas rendering inside React (i.e. what you're doing here).

In react how to do u select an element?  In vue there is v-bind, v-model.
Using refs https://reactjs.org/docs/refs-and-the-dom.html
<div ref={(ref)=>this.myVariable=ref}/>
or <div ref={(ref)this.myFunction(ref)} />
Why is that? I use it to add more than one eventListeners to a div. Is that bad practice?
what kind of event listeners?
mouseenter mouseleave click

Joe Bien you are using React wrongly mate. The correct way to do it is <Component onMouseEnter={handler1} onMouseLeave={handler2} onClick={handler3} />

https://reactjs.org/docs/events.html
Gan Wei Jian It just seems more organized to put everything in one function. What is the advantage of using the onMouseEnter etc.?
does it really make a difference?
How about using the ref call back to make some change on the element holding the eventlistener?
When do you use the ref callback ? Just for setting a variable to reference the element or component?

if you use "addEventListener" on the ref, you have to make sure that the event listener is removed when the DOM is removed, and prevent adding again when the DOM is rerendered. React's onMouseEnter does this for you, efficiently.
Joe Bien Yes that is a bad practice.
That is a VERY bad practice in fact. :) If you want to add multiple event listeners you just pass it one event listener that calls all the function that you want to execute. React is not a jQuery.
Yes. This is bad. Plus it's actually tidier if you write it the correct way :)

Refs shouldn't be used for this purpose. If you do controlled inputs just use the value and set your state at onChange. When you need to select your element you have to rethink what you have done, because it's wrong for sure. Don't add onmouseenter or other functions that way, just add them to the node in the JSX like: <div onMouseEnter={this.foo}/> and use getters instead
Ok. Thanks folks. It's been an education.
In react usually if you need to select an element you are doing something wrong 🙂
in rare cases its necessary - eg focusing inputs

Guys are you serious? In react you don't select elements. That is an anti-pattern. Vue uses two way data binding. React uses one way data flow. You don't select elements in react. You render them the way you want.

When creating a to-do list in React, do you use ref's?
Every article I read says you should not use ref's, unless you absolutely have to. They also say that people use ref's unnecessarily.
I can make a todo list with or without REF's. What is the better method?
I've never come across a case where you would use refs. Just give me very the time a value?
Thanks for the help!

If you can help it, do not use refs :) Almost everything you need to do can be passed using props
https://reactjs.org/docs/refs-and-the-dom.html

If you need to use refs for something so simple what you really need is to work on the React tutorials or read their guide.  This is React basics and only you can help yourself understand. Read the guide.

Sorry Crystal, I didn't mean to sound snide. I have read many tutorials when I started and I never had to use refs or saw any that uses refs, so I automatically assumed people who never read the tutorials ask this sort of questions. It's just not something you see commonly and should be avoided.

Gan Wei Jian thanks, I was looking for some feedback. From a developers side I never seen the need to use them. I was taking the code school tutorial to see if it had anything good. They show a main demo using ref’s.  I wonder why they are teaching people this? They should be teaching them the correct way to do something.

Well I can only say that not everything you see on the Internet is correct or true. Once you get the hang of things the best and fastest way to learn is through the documentation. Official documentation can't be wrong :)

Thanks @Gan, I have read the guide many times.  I have probably read it more than you. That is why I am asking the question. There are so many articles that teach people to use refs. If its bad form it should be stated as so.

I think about the only time I use refs is to use them as a callback to fetch the specific DOM node for whatever element, if I need to call getBoundingClientRect() on it (for example). Otherwise, it's best to avoid them. And never use string refs, only ref callbacks.
Ref's are sort of the last-solution thing I arrive at, it's usually the sign of bad structure that should be solved in the first place.

Some people ask me how to keep their redux state because it is lost after website reload.

Answer: you can use redux-persist to save your redux state on local storage/session storage. It will reload your state when app is reloaded.

Just one problem, there is a small delay time when redux-persist is loading your redux state. So you have to check the existence of your props before using them in your React component.

That is what Graphql does.

It's designed to solve some issues with REST apis.  For example you'll usually see an end point like https://.../users/id.  In this case, you may over fetch data, when all you care about is the username, first name and last name.  With GraphQL you design the schema and query exactly what you need, instead of retrieving everything and then just using what you're after.  Of course you can design a bunch of endpoints using REST, or create end points with a whole bunch of parameters, and both are really undesirable.  The beauty in GraphQL is you design the schema on how relationships are built (or graphed together).  I'm still learning, but from what I've seen so far, I love it.

Javascript has two groups of "types": Primitives, and Objects. Arrays are Objects, and Functions are (almost) like Objects too.
The rule of the thumb is: Primitives get copied, while Objects are referenced. That way, you didn't copy obj_1 to obj_2, you just referenced it from another place. When you mutated it, you didn't mutate obj1 nor obj2, you mutated the place where obj1 and obj2 are referencing ;)

actually its not a reference to obj1, its a reference to where obj1 is pointing (where the object is alocated). if that was true, setting obj1=null would cause obj2 to be null as well, but that is not true

When you render items normally, react uses the position of the item to identify the component, when you use dynamic data structure like arrays, it cannot do that, so you need to tell react what's what using keys.
It depends on the context. Sometimes index as keys are alright. Though majority of the time they are not.
It's only a problem if the order of the items will change - the React docs are quite clear on this.

That also means that when you have 4 items and you delete 1 item. Second item will take first items place and change its behavior a little. :) It is not a major issue but beginner developers tend to make some bugs because of this.

Try NOT TO USE INDEX as item key when iterating over items. 

https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/blob/master/docs/rules/no-array-index-key.md
Keys using an index iteration is never a great idea...
u need to use function(item,i) as args then use key={i} in side def
From the docs: "Keys should be given to the elements inside the array to give the elements a stable identity:" So arrays require keys

Try this :

this.test.map(function(item,index){return <button key={index}>{item}</button>})

React needs a special 'key' prop added to elements in an array, so that it can keep track of items being changed, added or removed (as well as enabling some performance optimisations). Each 'key' must be unique within the array ─ if you're iterating over a dataset with a unique ID on each item, use that; if not, an array index will do, although this isn't ideal.

More detail in React docs here: https://reactjs.org/docs/lists-and-keys.html

When you render an array of items, they must have an id. an example would be like a <ul> and an <li>... if an array is used to populate the <li>'s using an array, each li must have an ID associated with it (eg: a db ID or something unique, through the use of a key= prop. It is how react keeps track of these mapping from an array.

Depending on scenarios we can choose what to use:
1. One domain with frontend and server both eg: FE: example.com, API: example.com/api
- Use localStorage to store your token (JWT)

2. One domain with Server Side Rendering
- Use cookies to store your token

3. Multiple domains, eg: FE: example.com, API: api.example.com
- Use localStorage

4. Multiple domains with SSR
- User localStorage along with Cookie or only Cookie

Example implementation of 4th option can be found here: https://github.com/atulmy/crate

I do not see the problem to store token anywhere.

Do you have some advice to make the thing faster or  an other library I can use to render long pdf ? 

Thank you all :)

One thing that may improve your build performance is to use a cheaper type of sourcemap - I have found this makes a significant difference to the build time. Check out the webpack docs for sourcemap options!

Unfortunately this is just something that will happen as your bundle grows, especially with older versions of webpack, or with particularly large dependencies like react-pdf.

If you don't need control over the rendered content, then you should consider serving the PDF directly via an iframe - most modern browsers will have no problem with this (and be a lot faster than pdfjs)

IMO it's just a big security hole waiting to be hacked.
Thank you Sam Hulick.

Agreed, I have tested using WP as an api and in addition to being a security hole all on its own, it's slower than a snail crawling over peanut butter.

In a postman test getting 1 single post took 2 seconds cached from a server 100ms away. Getting a substantially larger payload on an api I setup very poorly for something else, with the DB in USA, api server in Ireland and me in south Africa the uncached request was 350ms.

So a larger payload that had to traverse 4 contentions was over 4x faster than 1 blog post on a cached WP site in the same city.

No point coupling one of the fastest ui frameworks with probably the slowest api solution.
Reme Le Hane Thank you  for sharing you experience :)
WordPress, ugh. I'd strongly recommend Contentful if you want a backend to just create pages, blog posts, etc, to be accessed via API by your React app. https://www.contentful.com/
